The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairscommented to the Cabinet on Sir Fame' Howard'sstatement to the Press in America to the effectthat0 now that the 15 Cruiser Bill had become law, it was likely that a further effort wouldbe made before long to reach agreement betweenthe principal Naval Powers for the limitation ofnaval armaments. Sir Austen Chamberlain believedthat the origin of this incident was a statement the himself had made to the American Press Corres-coorespondents in London at a private luncheon, as theresult of which one Correspondent had sent hiseditor a private communication to the effect that conversations would probably be resumed at anearly date. This had been shown to Sir EsmeHoward, who, wishing to avoid any appearance ofrudeness by making no comment, had issued thestatement referred to. What Sir Esm had said wasnot particularly indiscreet, but it did not perhapssufficiently emphasize that conversations werenot likely to take place immediately, in spite ofhis reference to the fact that the English Elec-tion would probably postpone discussion for sememonths. Consequently Sir Austen Chamberlain had thought it right to issue a statement to theeffect that the situation had not changed since he informed the House of Commons on February 6ththat His Majesty's Government were engaged incareful examination or all questions concerningour relations with America and the naval conditions-of the two countries.Sir Austen Chamberlain added that on theprevious day he had had a conversation with the f 18American Ambassador, who had referred to a phrase-used by the Prime Minister in his speech at theDinner in connection with the British IndustriesPair expressing the hope that if any nation wishedto quarrel the other nations of the world would say "Move on". This had corresponded with MrHoughtonTs own thought, and he had asked if thePrime Minister' e intention had been that, if war broke out( all neutrals should place an embargo on the supply of arms to both belligerents until it had been determined which was the aggressor.Sir Austen Chamberlain had indicated that thePrime Minister had probably not intended so muchas that0 This episode, however, illustrated thedesire in America for some kind of sanction for breaches of the peace.Sir Austen Chamberlain had taken this oppcrtu-nity to tell the Ambassador what, of course, healready knew that the Government were examiningall these questions relating to Anglo-american relations; that the Arbitration Treaty was mixedup with the question of Belligerent Rights at Sea,as was the Naval question generally.
